title: Chinese Government provides digital equipment and professional training assistance to Cuban state TV in September 2021
description: On September 20, 2021, the Chinese Government donated digital equipment and professional training assistance to help embargo-inflicted Cuba upgrade its state TV channels. The donation included two high-definition studios, a master control room, and training for Cuban state TV technicians from Chinese experts. The new digital technology provided by China equipped Cuba with a master control room with the capacity to transmit signals of 12 TV channels in unison if required. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government provides digital equipment and professional training assistance to Cuban state TV in September 2021

# Description
On September 20, 2021, the Chinese Government donated digital equipment and professional training assistance to help embargo-inflicted Cuba upgrade its state TV channels. The donation included two high-definition studios, a master control room, and training for Cuban state TV technicians from Chinese experts. The new digital technology provided by China equipped Cuba with a master control room with the capacity to transmit signals of 12 TV channels in unison if required. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on digital equipment donation and training for media infrastructure, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Digital equipment donation, professional training assistance, focus on state TV channel upgrades

title: SICOMINES provides 300,000 USD in disaster relief funds and anti-epidemic materials to the government of the DRC in July 2021
description: On July 17, 2021, a handover ceremony was held for SICOMINES's donation of USD $300,000 of epidemic prevention materials and disaster relief funds, as well as some epidemic protective materials with a value of USD $500,000 to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The material donation included masks, coveralls, and other supplies to help protect workers from the pandemic. The aid was intended to assist victims of the 2021 eruption of Mount Nyiragongo in North Kivu, which killed 32 and wounded 1,000 Congolese citizens on May 22, 2021.  Prime Minister Jean-Michel Sama Lukonde, the Congolese Minister of Health, the Congolese Minister of Social Affairs, and other senior Congolese government officials attended the event. Prime Minister Lukonde expressed gratitude for the assistance, and Ambassador Zhu Jing noted that the Huagang Mining Company's donation demonstrated the strong bond between China and the DRC.
staff_comments: 1. The transaction amount coded includes the monetary donation, as well as the value of the material donation.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
SICOMINES provides 300,000 USD in disaster relief funds and anti-epidemic materials to the government of the DRC in July 2021

# Description
On July 17, 2021, a handover ceremony was held for SICOMINES's donation of USD $300,000 of epidemic prevention materials and disaster relief funds, as well as some epidemic protective materials with a value of USD $500,000 to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The material donation included masks, coveralls, and other supplies to help protect workers from the pandemic. The aid was intended to assist victims of the 2021 eruption of Mount Nyiragongo in North Kivu, which killed 32 and wounded 1,000 Congolese citizens on May 22, 2021.  Prime Minister Jean-Michel Sama Lukonde, the Congolese Minister of Health, the Congolese Minister of Social Affairs, and other senior Congolese government officials attended the event. Prime Minister Lukonde expressed gratitude for the assistance, and Ambassador Zhu Jing noted that the Huagang Mining Company's donation demonstrated the strong bond between China and the DRC.
justification: Project focuses on disaster relief and epidemic prevention, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Disaster relief funds, anti-epidemic materials, masks, coveralls, assistance for volcanic eruption victims

title: Chinese Government donates 400,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $7.2 million in September 2021
description: On September 29, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 400,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The vaccines were intended to complement other already available vaccines in the DRC, such as Astra Zeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer. The donation took place during a handover ceremony at N'Djili International airport. Those in attendance included the Congolese Minister of Public Health, Hygiene and Prevention Jean-Jacques Mbungani Mbanda, the Chinese Ambassador to the DRC Zhu Jing, experts from UNICEF and WHO, and other Congolese officials. At the event, Ambassador Zhu Jing and Minister Jean-Jacques Mbungani signed an act of delivery and receipt of the vaccines.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the September 2021 donation as $7.2 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 400,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $7.2 million in September 2021

# Description
On September 29, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 400,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The vaccines were intended to complement other already available vaccines in the DRC, such as Astra Zeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer. The donation took place during a handover ceremony at N'Djili International airport. Those in attendance included the Congolese Minister of Public Health, Hygiene and Prevention Jean-Jacques Mbungani Mbanda, the Chinese Ambassador to the DRC Zhu Jing, experts from UNICEF and WHO, and other Congolese officials. At the event, Ambassador Zhu Jing and Minister Jean-Jacques Mbungani signed an act of delivery and receipt of the vaccines.
justification: Project is a vaccine donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 400,000 donated vaccine doses, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government cancels RMB 180 million of the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo's (DRC) outstanding debt obligations (linked to Project ID# 93017)
description: On January 7, 2021, the Chinese Government announced that it was cancelling RMB 180 million (USD 28 million) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo's (DRC) outstanding debt obligations. The debt obligations come from interest-free loans that the Chinese government provided to the DRC. The debt obligations were originally due to mature at the end of 2020. The purpose of this cancellation is primarily to help DRC develop infrastructure.  The cancelation was announced in a joint press conference between the Chinese and DRC governments in Kinshasa. At the event, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said the purpose of the cancellations was to provide financial relief from the burdens of the COVID-19 pandemic.   China has granted over USD 2 billion in debt relief to developing countries that faced financial burdens from the COVID-19 pandemic. The relief comes from a G-20 framework. In addition to the debt relief, the Chinese government provided USD 17 million in financial support for the DRC government (Project ID# 93017). DRC signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to become the 45th African country to enter the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). China also donated 100,000 doses of the coronavirus vaccine alongside this agreement (see: Project ID# 97642).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels RMB 180 million of the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo's (DRC) outstanding debt obligations (linked to Project ID# 93017)

# Description
On January 7, 2021, the Chinese Government announced that it was cancelling RMB 180 million (USD 28 million) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo's (DRC) outstanding debt obligations. The debt obligations come from interest-free loans that the Chinese government provided to the DRC. The debt obligations were originally due to mature at the end of 2020. The purpose of this cancellation is primarily to help DRC develop infrastructure.  The cancelation was announced in a joint press conference between the Chinese and DRC governments in Kinshasa. At the event, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said the purpose of the cancellations was to provide financial relief from the burdens of the COVID-19 pandemic.   China has granted over USD 2 billion in debt relief to developing countries that faced financial burdens from the COVID-19 pandemic. The relief comes from a G-20 framework. In addition to the debt relief, the Chinese government provided USD 17 million in financial support for the DRC government (Project ID# 93017). DRC signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to become the 45th African country to enter the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). China also donated 100,000 doses of the coronavirus vaccine alongside this agreement (see: Project ID# 97642).
justification: Debt cancellation and financial relief without specific environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt cancellation for COVID-19 relief, no specific project details linking to environmental or energy transition goals

title: Chinese Government provides USD $17 million in financial support to the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) in January 2021 (linked to Project ID# 93016)
description: On January 7, 2021, it was announced that the Chinese Government provided USD $17 million in financial support to the government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). The support was intended to alleviate burdens from the COVID-19 pandemic. USD $15 million of the USD $17 million was intended to be channeled towards development projects and the remaining USD 2 million was intended to be used to support the DRC's mandate as head of the African Union bloc.  The financial support was announced in a joint press conference between the Chinese and DRC governments in Kinshasa. In addition to the financial support, the Chinese government provided RMB 180 million in debt forgiveness to the DRC government (Project ID# 93106), and donated 100,000 vaccines (see: Project ID# 97692). These agreements were signed along with an agreement for the DRC to enter the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides USD $17 million in financial support to the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) in January 2021 (linked to Project ID# 93016)

# Description
On January 7, 2021, it was announced that the Chinese Government provided USD $17 million in financial support to the government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). The support was intended to alleviate burdens from the COVID-19 pandemic. USD $15 million of the USD $17 million was intended to be channeled towards development projects and the remaining USD 2 million was intended to be used to support the DRC's mandate as head of the African Union bloc.  The financial support was announced in a joint press conference between the Chinese and DRC governments in Kinshasa. In addition to the financial support, the Chinese government provided RMB 180 million in debt forgiveness to the DRC government (Project ID# 93106), and donated 100,000 vaccines (see: Project ID# 97692). These agreements were signed along with an agreement for the DRC to enter the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI).
justification: Project involves financial support and debt forgiveness without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: USD $17 million financial support, RMB 180 million debt forgiveness, COVID-19 pandemic relief focus

title: Chinese Government dispatches the 20th medical team to the Democratic Republic of the Congo COVID-19 relief
description: On November 16, 2021, the 20th Chinese medical team to the Democratic Republic of the Congo was dispatched from Shijiazhuang, Heibei Province, and flew to Ndjili, Kinshasa, where they were assigned to work at the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital for a one-year medical mission. The team was formed in January 2021 and consisted of 21 members. The purpose of their trip was to fulfill a previous agreement between the two governments to provide health services for the people of the DRC and participate in the prevention and control of COVID-19. Before embarking on their mission, they completed a 5-month training program.  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1973. However, due to internal turmoil, the Chinese Government stopped sending medical teams from 1997 to 2008. Hubei Province has been responsible for sending the medical teams.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches the 20th medical team to the Democratic Republic of the Congo COVID-19 relief

# Description
On November 16, 2021, the 20th Chinese medical team to the Democratic Republic of the Congo was dispatched from Shijiazhuang, Heibei Province, and flew to Ndjili, Kinshasa, where they were assigned to work at the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital for a one-year medical mission. The team was formed in January 2021 and consisted of 21 members. The purpose of their trip was to fulfill a previous agreement between the two governments to provide health services for the people of the DRC and participate in the prevention and control of COVID-19. Before embarking on their mission, they completed a 5-month training program.  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1973. However, due to internal turmoil, the Chinese Government stopped sending medical teams from 1997 to 2008. Hubei Province has been responsible for sending the medical teams.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services and COVID-19 relief, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team dispatched for health services and COVID-19 prevention, working at Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital

title: Chinese Government provides medical materials to the Civil House of the Head of State of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) in 2021
description: On July 1, 2021, representatives from the Chinese Embassy in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) handed over a donation of medical materials for the COVID-19 pandemic to the Civil House of the Head of State of the DRC. The materials donated included portable breathing apparatuses, oxygen generators, oxygen generator support pipelines, and masks. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from DRC Government in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).   Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $14,197,000 ($12,939,000 in principal payments and $1,258,000 in interest payments).   However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis.   Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022)
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from DRC Government in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).   Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $14,197,000 ($12,939,000 in principal payments and $1,258,000 in interest payments).   However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis.   Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial obligations and COVID-19 response

title: China donates 500 tons of rice to Djibouti in March 2021
description: On March 17, 2021, China donated 500 tons of rice to Djibouti to aid in the country's campaign against food insecurity. The donation ceremony was held at the National Office for Refugee and Disaster Assistance (ONARS), in the presence of the Chinese Ambassador to Djibouti, Zhuo Ruisheng, the Djiboutian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf, and the Minister of the Interior, Moumin Cheikh.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China donates 500 tons of rice to Djibouti in March 2021

# Description
On March 17, 2021, China donated 500 tons of rice to Djibouti to aid in the country's campaign against food insecurity. The donation ceremony was held at the National Office for Refugee and Disaster Assistance (ONARS), in the presence of the Chinese Ambassador to Djibouti, Zhuo Ruisheng, the Djiboutian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf, and the Minister of the Interior, Moumin Cheikh.
justification: Project is focused on food aid and social development, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Food donation for food security assistance, humanitarian focus

title: Chinese Government donates 200,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $3.6 million in March 2021
description: In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 1.3 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Djibouti. The Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Djibouti on March 18, 2021. Then, on November 30, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 1,100,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Djibouti.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the March 2021 donation as $3.6 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 200,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $3.6 million in March 2021

# Description
In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 1.3 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Djibouti. The Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Djibouti on March 18, 2021. Then, on November 30, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 1,100,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Djibouti.
justification: Project involves donation of vaccines for public health purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Vaccine donation, healthcare sector, public health focus
